poem:
The sign flickers 2-7-3-3-3 across the windshield—  
a constellation waking at midnight.

Metal breath hums beneath your feet when we pause  
at cracked pavement and neon-lit shelters.  
Each stop becomes a note, a low chant rising  
through the city’s ribs.

In the pale hush before doors swing open,  
we gather in half-dreams—eyelids heavy as moth wings.  
The hum lulls hearts toward that sweet nowhere  
just beyond the streetlamp glare.

At dawn’s edge, a cluster of geese stands guard  
on the asphalt runway. Their feathers glimmer  
like fallen starlight in the gutter.  
We do not yield. Their honks shatter windows of sleep;  
we press onward, humming louder—  
a bold refusal carved into iron wheels.

Inside, a child traces constellations on the window’s mist.  
An old man taps time with a battered cane.  
Somewhere beneath the rumble, a phantom conductor  
grins, guiding us through back alleys of memory  
and half-forgotten lullabies.

We fold ourselves into corridors of street noise—  
the hiss of brakes, the whisper of turning wheels,  
the passenger’s breath catching on an unseen turn.  
The route unfolds like a restless dream,  
casting sparks beneath every stoplight,  
leaving geese to their waterlogged vigil  
while we hum toward a sky that flickers possibility.
